thread.title: What happened to the UK markets as Donald Trump won the Presidential election?
thread.title_full: What happened to the UK markets as Donald Trump won the Presidential election?

author: Mike Kelly
title: What happened to the UK markets as Donald Trump won the Presidential election?
text:
What happened to the UK markets as Donald Trump won the Presidential election? Financial chaos some predicted if Trump wins presidency has so far not come to pass Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Donald Trump's acceptance speech in full after historic win Share this video Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The economic melt down some predicted if Donald Trump became US President came to pass - briefly. 
On the news that the controversial businessman and reality TV star had won the race to the White House, the FTSE 100, the share prices of the UK’s top 100 companies, fell by more than 130 points wiping £32bn off their value. 
However it has since bounced back to 6,836 as of 9.45am, having closed seven points higher at 6,843 last night. 
The effect has been similar to reaction to the Brexit vote on June 23 when the UK chose to leave the European Union, although the recovery has been much more rapid. 
Then the stock market plunged however, in this case, it took a week to recover and is now higher than its pre June 23 level. 
Meanwhile the FTSE 250, after an early morning plunge, is actually slightly up on the day. President-elect Donald Trump shakes hands with Vice President-elect Mike Pence (Photo: PA Wire) 
And the value of sterling against the dollar has recovered after weeks of battering during the US presidential campaign meaning it’s good news for people travelling across the Atlantic. 
The dollar has fallen in value compared to the pound. 
The pound at 9am was 1.2427 dollars compared to 1.2371 dollars at the previous close. 
The shock win by Republican candidate Trump has been predicted to send global markets into mayhem. Read More US Election 2016 LIVE: Donald Trump is elected president of the United States 
Some financial experts said that Wall Street could suffer its biggest ever plunge when Wednesday’s trading session begins as it gets to grips with the result. 
However we will have to wait and see if their doom mongering is justified as for the UK, just as after Brexit, the affect hasn’t been as disastrous as some experts predicted. Share
